Question_1.Context: Based on the experiment with the E. coli-H strain in the microbial electrolysis cell system, what was the observed effect of electricity on levoglucosan consumption and ethanol production?
Question_1.Question: What effect did the application of electricity have on levoglucosan consumption and ethanol production by the E. coli-H strain?
Question_1.A: Decreased levoglucosan consumption and ethanol production
Question_1.B: No significant change in levoglucosan consumption but increased ethanol production
Question_1.C: Increased levoglucosan consumption and ethanol production
Question_1.D: Increased levoglucosan consumption but decreased ethanol production
Question_1.Source: In electrically treated bio-oil media, the E. coli-H strain exhibited significantly higher levoglucosan consumption and ethanol production capacities compared with the control.

Question_2.Context: In the experiment, what was the bioethanol yield obtained by the E. coli-H strain in the electrified MEC system?
Question_2.Question: What was the bioethanol yield achieved by the E. coli-H strain in the electrified MEC system?
Question_2.Source: E. coli-H produced 0.54 g ethanol/g levoglucosan, reaching 94% of the theoretical yield.

Question_3.Context: Regarding inhibitor degradation performance, what was the observed effect of electricity on furfural conversion in the bio-oil-based microbial electrolysis cell system?
Question_3.Question: How did the application of electricity affect furfural conversion in the bio-oil-based microbial electrolysis cell system?
Question_3.Source: In the bioelectrochemical group, the concentration of furfural had dropped to approximately 2 × 10–8 mg/L at 56 h, which compares with the value of approximately 8.83 × 10–8 mg/L recorded at the same time point in the control fermentation.

Question_4.Context: What was the observed trend in Coulomb efficiency during the fermentation process in the MEC system?
Question_4.Question: What trend was observed in Coulomb efficiency during the fermentation process in the MEC system?
Question_4.Source: The Coulomb efficiency of the experimental group peaked at 80.3%, 66.8%, and 28.4% during the course of fermentation from 32 to 36 h, 36 h to 40 h, and 40 h to 44 h, respectively, thereby indicating that external energy is the main source for generating bioethanol during the fermentation process, although gradually declines in the latter stages.

Question_5.Context: What was the purpose of using neutral red in the experiment with E. coli in the microbial electrolysis cell system?
Question_5.Question: Why was neutral red used in the experiment with E. coli in the microbial electrolysis cell system?
Question_5.Source: Neutral red functions as a supplementary electron sink that accepts the excessive electrons produced during glycolysis, which are in turn used to regenerate NAD+ from NADH, which is beneficial for further glycolysis.

Question_6.Context: What was the observed effect of electricity on the growth of E. coli in the experiment?
Question_6.Question: How did the application of electricity affect the growth of E. coli in the experiment?
Question_6.Source: Notably, the application of electricity clearly stimulated the growth of E. coli and markedly diminished the necessary fermentation time.

Question_7.Context: What was the main benefit of the MEC system in the production of ethanol according to the experiment?
Question_7.Question: What was the primary advantage of the MEC system in ethanol production based on the experiment?
Question_7.Source: We conclude that the ethanol produced from the integrated process demonstrated in this study can be used to derive fuel from hydrodeoxygenated bio-oil, while reducing lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions.

Question_8.Context: What was the observed effect of the MEC system on inhibitor conversion in the bio-oil media?
Question_8.Question: How did the MEC system influence inhibitor conversion in the bio-oil media?
Question_8.Source: These findings thus indicate that microbial electrolysis can promote the efficient conversion of the organic acids and furfural in bio-oil.

Question_9.Context: What was the significance of the observed Coulomb efficiency in the MEC process?
Question_9.Question: Why is the Coulomb efficiency important in the MEC process?
Question_9.C: To assess the efficiency of bioethanol production
Question_9.Source: The Coulomb efficiency for the production of ethanol in the MEC process represents the ratio of the mass of ethanol liberated by a current to the theoretical mass, as predicted by Coulomb’s law.

Question_10.Context: What was the conclusion drawn regarding the application of the microbial electrosynthesis process for ethanol production?
Question_10.Question: What conclusion was reached regarding the use of the microbial electrosynthesis process for ethanol production?
Question_10.C: Enhanced ethanol productivity and reduced emissions
Question_10.Source: We conclude that the ethanol produced from the integrated process demonstrated in this study can be used to derive fuel from hydrodeoxygenated bio-oil, while reducing lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions.
